{{distinguish|Liberty dollar (private currency)}}
{{Infobox dot-com company | name = Liberty Reserve S.A. | logo = [[File:Liberty Reserve logo.svg|right|250px]] | company_type = [[Sociedad Anónima]] | type = [[E-commerce payment system]] | foundation = {{start date|2006}} | location = [[Costa Rica]] | launch_date = 2001 (?) | dissolved = {{end date|2013|5}} | services = Digital currency transfer | current_status = Inactive (taken offline by regulators) |}} '''Liberty Reserve''' was a [[Costa Rica]]-based centralized [[digital currency]] service that billed itself as the "oldest, safest and most popular payment processor, serving millions all around a world".<ref name=BBC>{{cite news|title=Liberty Reserve digital money service forced offline|date=May 27, 2013|publisher=BBC|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-22680297|accessdate=May 27, 2013}}</ref> The site had over one million users when it was shut down by the United States government. Prosecutors argued that due to lax security, alleged criminal activity largely went undetected, which ultimately led to them seizing the service.<ref name=NYTimes />
In May 2013, Liberty Reserve was shut down by United States federal prosecutors under the [[Patriot Act]] after an investigation by authorities across 17 countries. The United States charged founder Arthur Budovsky and six others with [[money laundering]] and operating an unlicensed financial transaction company. Liberty Reserve is alleged to have been used to launder more than $6 billion in criminal proceeds during its history.<ref name=ABC />
==Background== Based in [[San José, Costa Rica|San José]] [[Costa Rica]], Liberty Reserve was a centralized [[digital currency]] service that allowed users to register and transfer money to other users with only a name, e-mail address, and birth date.<ref name=BBC /> No efforts were made by the site to verify identities of its users, making it an attractive payment processor to scam artists.<ref name=ABC /> Deposits could be made through third parties using a credit card or bankwire, among other deposit options.<ref name=BBC /><ref name=NYTimes /> Liberty Reserve did not directly process deposits or withdrawals.<ref name=NYTimes /> Deposited funds were then "converted" into Liberty Reserve Dollars or Liberty Reserve Euros, which were tied to the value of the [[United States dollar|U.S. dollar]] and the [[euro]], respectively, or to ounces of gold.<ref name=BBC /><ref name=Tico /> No limits were placed on transaction sizes.<ref name=DMW /> The service made money by charging a small fee, about 1%, on each transfer.<ref name=BBC /> Transactions were "100% irrevocable".<ref name=DMW>{{cite news|title=Liberty Reserve - Interview with Mr. Joul Lee pt.1|work=Digital Money World|date=July 22, 2007}}</ref> Liberty Reserve also offered shopping cart functionality and other merchant services.<ref name=DMW />
Service was popular among currency brokers and [[multilevel marketing]] companies.<ref name=Tico /> According to Forex Magnates, a specialized [[forex]] news service, Liberty Reserve was "the leading payment channel for traders in emerging and frontier markets."<ref name=Tico /> Richard Weber, head of the U.S. [[Internal Revenue Service]] criminal investigation unit, declared, "If [[Al Capone]] were alive today, this is how he would be hiding his money".<ref name=NYTimes>{{cite news|title=Online Currency Exchange Accused of Laundering $6 Billion|author=Marc Santora|author2=William K. Rashbaum|author3=Nicole Perlroth|date=May 28, 2013|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/29/nyregion/liberty-reserve-operators-accused-of-money-laundering.html|accessdate=May 28, 2013}}</ref> At the time of its closure, Liberty Reserve had more than 1 million registered users, 200,000 of which were from the United States.<ref name=ABC /> It was a member of the [[Global Digital Currency Association]].<ref name=DMW />
Liberty employees were required to sign a confidentiality agreement to "maintain in strict confidentiality all information" about the company, including "administrative affairs, operations and financial details" for 15 years after leaving the company.<ref name=Tico2 /> Additionally they were required to notify management if issued a warrant to reveal such information.<ref name=Tico />
==History== From 2002 to 2006, United States businessmen Arthur Budovsky and Vladimir Kats ran a digital currency exchange service known as [[Gold Age]].<ref name=Tico /> In July 2006, the duo were indicted{{by whom|date=June 2013}} on charges of operating an illegal financial business, a [[felony]]. They were sentenced to five years in prison in 2007, but the sentence was reduced to five years of probation.<ref name=Tico /> Budovsky fled the country, settling in Costa Rica.<ref name=GlobalPost>{{cite news|title=Liberty Reserve digital money service shut down, founder arrested|author=Jill Langlois|date=May 27, 2013|work=GlobalPost|url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/business/technology/130527/liberty-reserve-digital-money-service-shut-down-founder-arrested|accessdate=May 28, 2013}}</ref> He subsequently became a naturalized citizen of Costa Rica when he married a Costa Rican woman in 2010, and renounced his American citizenship in 2012.<ref name=Nacion>{{cite news|title=España captura a costarricense por lavado de dinero a pedido de Estados Unidos|trans-title=Spain captures Costa Rican money launderer upon U.S. request|author=Carlos Arguedas C.|date=May 25, 2013|work=La Nacion|url=http://www.nacion.com/2013-05-25/Sucesos/espana-captura-a-costarricense-por-lavado-de-dinero-a-pedido-de-estados-unidos.aspx|language=Spanish|accessdate=May 28, 2013}}</ref><ref name=marriage />
Liberty Reserve was incorporated by Budovsky in Costa Rica in 2006.<ref name=NYTimes /> A 2007 interview with Joul Lee, the company's marketing manager, claimed it was founded as "a private currency exchange system for import/export businesses" and opened to the public in 2007.<ref name=DMW />
===Criminal investigation and charges=== Costa Rican authorities became aware of Liberty Reserve in 2009 and informed the business it needed a license to operate as a money transmitting business.<ref name=Tico2>{{cite news|title=Costa Rican President Chinchilla denies link to Liberty Reserve attorney|date=May 31, 2013|work=Tico Times|url=http://www.ticotimes.net/More-news/News-Briefs/Costa-Rican-President-Chinchilla-denies-link-to-Liberty-Reserve-attorney-_Friday-May-31-2013|accessdate=May 31, 2013}}</ref> In 2011, Liberty Reserve was denied a business license in Costa Rica, according to state prosecutor José Pablo González, due to lack of transparency about how the business was funded. The business formally disbanded at that time, but company founder Arthur Budovsky continued to operate the business by funneling it through five other Costa Rican businesses, according to authorities.<ref name=BBC /> A criminal investigation was launched March 7, 2011 following "suspicious" bank activity.<ref name=Tico2 /> Later in 2011, the United States authorities asked Costa Rica to begin investigating Budovsky's business dealings.<ref name=Tico>{{cite news|title=Millions of dollars in limbo after shuttering of digital currency site Liberty Reserve|author=David Boddiger|author2=L. Arias|work=Tico Times|date=May 25, 2013|url=http://www.ticotimes.net/More-news/News-Briefs/Millions-of-dollars-in-limbo-after-shuttering-of-digital-currency-site-Liberty-Reserve-_Saturday-May-25-2013|accessdate=May 28, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131231234813/http://www.ticotimes.net/More-news/News-Briefs/Millions-of-dollars-in-limbo-after-shuttering-of-digital-currency-site-Liberty-Reserve-_Saturday-May-25-2013|archivedate=December 31, 2013|df=}}</ref> According to Bernardita Marín, associate director of the Costa Rican Drug Institute, Costa Rica seized funds from Liberty Reserve on three occasions from 2011 to 2013.<ref name=Tico2 />
In 2011, Liberty Reserve was linked to (unrelated) attempts to sell thousands of stolen Australian bank account numbers and British bank cards.<ref>{{cite news|title=Frenzied bidding for stolen identities|work=Sunday Herald Sun|date=July 10, 2011|page=15}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=On sale at £3.70: your stolen credit details|work=The Sunday Times|author=Mazher Mahmood|author2=Mark Hookham|date=November 6, 2011}}</ref> In 2012, a group of [[hacker (computer security)|hacker]]s attempted to [[blackmail]] anti-virus software company [[Symantec]] into transferring $50,000 into a Liberty Reserve account.<ref>{{cite news|title=Symantec Says Hackers Tried Extortion|work=The New York Times Bits Blog|date=February 7, 2012|author=Nicole Perlroth}}</ref>
====2013 seizure==== [[File:Liberty Reserve seizure.png|thumb|300px|right|[[Domain name]] seizure notice, citing {{uscsub|18|982|a|1}}]]
After a multi-year investigation by officials in 17 countries, a sealed indictment was issued by the U.S. government in May 2013.<ref name=ABC /> U.S. prosecutors filed a case against Liberty Reserve, alleging it had handled $6 billion of criminal proceeds.<ref name=ABC /> Arthur Budovsky was arrested by Spanish police at Madrid's [[Adolfo Suárez Madrid–Barajas Airport|Barajas International Airport]] as he attempted to return to Costa Rica where he had citizenship.<ref>{{cite news|title=Boss of digital-currency operator Liberty Reserve arrested in Spain|agency=Agencia EFE|work=GlobalPost|date=May 28, 2013|url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/agencia-efe/130528/boss-digital-currency-operator-liberty-reserve-arrested-spain|accessdate=May 30, 2013}}</ref><ref name="usat">{{cite news |title=Costa Rica probes Liberty Reserve founder marriage |date=May 30, 2013 |newspaper=USA Today |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/business/2013/05/30/budovsky-liberty-reserve/2371445/ }}</ref> Budovsky and a second man were ordered jailed by Spanish authorities pending an extradition hearing.<ref name="usat"/> Earlier three homes and the five apparent shell businesses owned by Budovsky were raided.<ref name=AP>{{cite news|title=Costa Rica: Digital currency site founder arrested|author=Javier Cordoba|author2=Raphael Satter|work=Bloomberg Businessweek|url=http://www.businessweek.com/ap/2013-05-27/costa-rica-digital-currency-site-founder-arrested|date=May 27, 2013|accessdate=May 28, 2013}}</ref> Four others, including Kats, were arrested across three countries: Costa Rica, Spain, and the United States. Two others are at large in Costa Rica.<ref name=ABC />
The Liberty Reserve website was taken offline on May 24 and replaced with a notice saying the domain had been "seized by the United States Global Illicit Financial Team."<ref name=BBC /><ref name="Guard-1">{{cite web | url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/may/28/liberty-reserve-arthur-budovsky-arrested-spain | title=Liberty Reserve founder arrested in Spain | publisher=Guardian | date=2013-05-28 | accessdate=2013-05-29}}</ref> In Costa Rica, a court order was issued to seize the "financial products and services" of Budovsky, Maxim Chukharev, and the six apparent [[Shell corporation|shell companies]].<ref name=Tico2 /> More than a million dollars of luxury automobiles alone were seized.<ref name=Tico2 />
The indictment, unsealed on May 28, charges the seven principal employees, as well as Liberty Reserve itself, with money laundering and operating an unlicensed money transmitting business, and seeks $25 million in damages.<ref name=ABC /> The charges were leveled using a provision of the [[Patriot Act]], since Liberty Reserve was not an American company.<ref name=NYTimes /> The accused could face up to 30 years in prison.<ref name=NYTimes />
[[Preet Bharara]], a United States prosecutor working on the case called Liberty Reserve a "black market bank", created and structured to "facilitate criminal activity".<ref name=ABC>{{cite news|title='Black Market Bank' Accused of Laundering $6B in Criminal Proceeds|author=Jack Cloherty|date=May 28, 2013|work=[[ABC News]]|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/black-market-bank-accused-laundering-6b-criminal-proceeds/story?id=19275887|accessdate=May 28, 2013}}</ref> In total, Liberty Reserve "processed an estimated 55 million separate financial transactions and is believed to have laundered more than $6 billion in criminal proceeds". It has been linked to crimes including [[credit card fraud]], [[identity theft]], [[Securities fraud|investment fraud]], [[Hacker|computer hacking]], [[child pornography]] and [[Illegal drug trade|narcotics trafficking]].<ref name=ABC />
Liberty Reserve itself was accused by U.S. prosecutors of moving tens of millions of dollars through shell accounts.<ref name=ABC /> Forty-five bank accounts were seized or restricted by United States federal prosecutors under the Patriot Act as a result of the investigation.<ref name=NYTimes /> The U.S. attorney in Manhattan, Preet Bharara, stated the case "may be the largest international money laundering case ever brought by the United States."<ref name=ABC /> "The global enforcement action we announce today is an important step towards reining in the 'Wild West' of illicit Internet banking," Bharara said; "As crime goes increasingly global, the long arm of the law has to get even longer, and in this case, it encircled the earth."<ref name=ABC />
One specific allegation of the prosecutors is that the site played a role in [[money laundering|laundering]] the $45 million stolen from the [[BankMuscat|Bank of Muscat]] and the [[RAKBANK|National Bank of Ras Al Khaimah]] in May 2013.<ref name=AP /><ref name="45 million">The sum of $45 million was reported stolen from the [[BankMuscat]] and the [[RAKBANK|National Bank of Ras Al Khaimah]] earlier in the month - {{cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/100727531|title=Germany Arrests Two for $45 Million Cyber Bank Heist|date=2013-05-10|publisher=CNBC|accessdate=2013-05-30}}</ref>
==Aftermath== According to Internet security analyst [[Brian Krebs]], the closure of Liberty Reserve had the potential to "cause a major upheaval in the cybercrime economy".<ref name=BBC /> The closure of the site led to many individuals using the service for legitimate reasons losing access to their money.<ref name="BBC-1"/> The head of EPay Tarjeta, a service which used Liberty Reserve, remarked "We seem to be acceptable collateral damage ... we have committed no crime."<ref name="BBC-1">{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-22686777 | title=US prosecutes '$6bn money-laundering hub' | publisher=BBC | accessdate=2013-05-29}}</ref>
United States attorney [[Preet Bharara]] stated users of Liberty Reserve could contact his office to inquire about getting their funds returned.<ref name=NYTimes />
On May 29, Budovsky's wife came forward with an accusation that she had been paid $800 to marry him in 2010 so that he could become a Costa Rican citizen. According to her, the plan was to divorce two years later, although the couple were still married at the time of his arrest.<ref name=marriage>{{cite news|title=Costa Rica probes Liberty Reserve founder marriage|agency=Associated Press|date=May 30, 2013|work=USA Today|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/business/2013/05/30/budovsky-liberty-reserve/2371445/|accessdate=Feb 1, 2016}}</ref>
In December 2014, [[chief technology officer]] Mark Marmilev was given the maximum sentence of five years after pleading guilty to operating an "unlicensed money transmitting business."<ref name=conviction>{{cite news|title=Liberty Reserve CTO and eBay car scammer jailed for 5 years each|author=John Hawes|date=December 14, 2014|work=Naked Security|url=https://nakedsecurity.sophos.com/2014/12/14/liberty-reserve-cto-and-ebay-car-scammer-jailed-for-5-years-each/|accessdate=Dec 16, 2014}}</ref>
In January 2016, Arthur Budovsky pleaded guilty to one count of conspiring to commit money laundering.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/founder-liberty-reserve-pleads-guilty-laundering-more-250-million-through-his-digital |date=January 29, 2016 |publisher=[[U.S. Department of Justice]] Office of Public Affairs |title=Founder of Liberty Reserve Pleads Guilty to Laundering More Than $250 Million through His Digital Currency Business}}</ref> On May 6, 2016, Budovsky was sentenced to 20 years in prison.<ref>{{cite web |title=Liberty Reserve Founder Arthur Budovsky Sentenced In Manhattan Federal Court To 20 Years For Laundering Hundreds Of Millions Of Dollars Through His Global Digital Currency Business |url=https://www.justice.gov/usao-sdny/pr/liberty-reserve-founder-arthur-budovsky-sentenced-manhattan-federal-court-20-years |website=United States Department of Justice |accessdate=17 August 2018 |date=6 May 2016}}</ref>
==See also== * [[e-gold]]
==References== {{reflist|35em}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/*/libertyreserve.com LibertyReserve.com] at Archive.org *[http://www.justice.gov/usao/nys/pressreleases/May13/LibertyReservePR/Liberty%20Reserve,%20et%20al.%20Indictment%20-%20Redacted.pdf US Justice Department indictment (redacted)] against Liberty Reserve

revision.text:
{{Outdated as of | topic = Current models | year = 2013 | month = 11 | day = 24 }} [[File:Xbox-360-Pro-wController.jpg|thumb|upright|right|Xbox 360 Pro console with white wireless controller.]] The '''[[Xbox 360]]''' video game console has appeared in various '''retail configurations''' during its life-cycle. At its launch, the Xbox 360 was available in two retail configurations: the morning "Xbox 360" package (unofficially known as the 20 GB Pro or Premium), priced at [[United States dollar|US$]]399.99 or [[Pound sterling|£]]279.99, and the "Xbox 360 Core," priced at US$299.99 and £209.99. The original shipment of Xbox 360s included a cut-down version of the Media Remote as a promotion. The Elite package was launched later at a retail price of US$479.99. The "Xbox 360 Core" was replaced by the "Xbox 360 Arcade" in October 2007<ref name=ArcadeConsolePR>{{cite web|url= http://www.microsoft.com/Presspass/press/2007/oct07/10-22ArcadeConsolePR.mspx|title= Microsoft Launches New Xbox 360 Console for Families|accessdate= 2008-07-26|date= 2007-10-22|publisher= Microsoft Corporation}}</ref> and a 60 GB version of the Xbox 360 Pro was released on August 1, 2008. The Pro package was discontinued and marked down to US$249.99 on August 28, 2009 to be sold until stock ran out, while the Elite was also marked down in price to US$299.99.<ref name="usatoday1">{{cite news|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/gamehunters/post/2009/08/microsoft-drops-price-of-120gb-xbox-360-system-/1 |title=Microsoft drops price of 120 GB Xbox 360 system — Game Hunters: In search of video games and interactive awesomeness |publisher=Content.usatoday.com |date=2009-08-27 |accessdate=2009-09-10}}</ref>
In June 2010, Microsoft announced a new, redesigned, model and the discontinuation of the Elite and Arcade models.<ref name="360 Arcade replacement" />
==Current models (Xbox 360 S and Xbox 360 E)== [[File:Xbox-360S-Console-Set.jpg|thumb|upright|Xbox 360 S console (Matte black)|alt=Xbox 360 S console]]<!--Image placed on the left to avoid stacking with the infobox on larger screens (or when fully expanded) --> Technically designated the '''Xbox 360 S''',<ref name="TomsGuide360S">{{cite web |url=http://www.tomsguide.com/us/xbox-360-slim-s-360-s-xbox-slim,news-7133.html |title=New Xbox 360 is Actually Called the Xbox 360 'S' |work=Tom's Guide |publisher=Purch, Inc. |accessdate=2010-06-22 |quote=Even though Microsoft is still calling it the same name as old, the sticker on the back shows clearly that it's the Xbox 360 '''S''' – perhaps taking a page out of Porsche naming conventions.}}</ref> commonly known as the '''Xbox 360 Slim''',<ref name="CNETXbox360Slim">{{cite web |url=http://www.cnet.com/products/microsoft-xbox-360-slim/ |title=Microsoft Xbox 360 Slim |work=CNET |date=2010-06-24}}</ref> and marketed simply as the '''Xbox 360''';<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.microsoft.com/Presspass/press/2010/jun10/06-14E3UmbrellaPR.mspx |title=Xbox 360 Transforms the Way Everyone Has Fun |date=June 14, 2010 |publisher=Microsoft |accessdate=2010-06-16 |quote=The New Xbox 360}}</ref> current Xbox 360 consoles are based on a redesign of the Xbox 360 hardware which was officially announced on June 14, 2010 during a press briefing prior to that year's [[Electronic Entertainment Expo|E3]]. It was speculated that a complete redesign of the Xbox 360 hardware was being produced after pictures of a possible new motherboard design surfaced on March 17, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|title=Xbox 360 Slim in the Works?|url=http://www.industrygamers.com/news/xbox-360-slim-in-the-works/|accessdate=May 1, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100323100913/http://www.industrygamers.com/news/xbox-360-slim-in-the-works/|archivedate=March 23, 2010|df=}}</ref> Ads later surfaced on June 13, 2010 showing a slimmer Xbox 360 design, which was expected to include a 250 GB hard drive and integrated Wi-Fi functionality.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/5562412/so-whats-inside-the-new-xbox-360 |title=So What's Inside The New Xbox 360? |work=[[Kotaku]] |date=2010-06-13 |accessdate=2010-11-11}}</ref>
The console's casing is revised in comparison to the previous models, with a glossy black finish and capacitive power and eject buttons.<ref name="insidenewxbox"/> The internal hardware was redesigned using a new motherboard codenamed "Valhalla", which integrates the CPU, GPU, and eDRAM into a single package using a 45 nm fabrication process. As the CPU and GPU are integrated into the same die, they may also share the same [[heatsink]] and fan, which reduces the console's noise output, and its power consumption by roughly half in comparison to the original Xenon motherboard.<ref name="insidenewxbox">{{cite web|url=http://www.anandtech.com/show/3774/welcome-to-valhalla-inside-the-new-250gb-xbox-360-slim|title=Inside the New Xbox 360 |author=Anand Lal Shimpi|authorlink=anandtech|date=2010-06-18|work=[[AnandTech]]|doi=|accessdate=2010-06-19}}</ref><ref name="insidenewxbox"/><ref name="engadgetnewxbox"/> The S has two additional rear USB ports, as well as a proprietary port used to connect the [[Kinect]] sensor.<ref name="engadgetnewxbox"/><ref name="insidenewxbox"/>
The motherboard has an integrated 2.4 GHz [[IEEE 802.11|802.11 b/g/n]] Wi-Fi adapter,<ref name="insidenewxbox"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2010/06/15/new-xbox-360-guide-microsofts-slim-console-explained/3|title=New Xbox 360 guide: Microsoft's slim console explained|publisher=[[Engadget]]|accessdate=2010-07-01|date=2010-06-15|quote=Biggest news on the connectivity front is 802.11n WiFi built-in. Interestingly the system detects it as if it were connected externally, but it's right in there, meaning no dongles for you (unless if you want 5GHz 802.11n, this one is single band 2.4GHz)}}</ref> and a [[TOSLINK]] [[S/PDIF]] optical audio connector.<ref name="engadgetnewxbox">{{cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2010/06/14/slim-xbox-360-gets-official-at-299-shipping-today-looks-angul/|title=New Xbox 360 looks angular and Ominous |first=Nilay|last=Patel|author=|authorlink=Engadget|date=2010-06-14|publisher=[[Engadget]]|doi=|accessdate=2010-06-14}}</ref> The S no longer includes [[Xbox 360 accessories#Memory units|Memory Unit]] slots; USB drives can alternatively be used to expand storage.<ref name="insidenewxbox"/> The external hard disk drive connector has also been swapped for an internal bay for use with a proprietary hard drive. The hard drive bay is designed such that a specially formatted 2.5' hard drive may be loaded in.<ref name="insidenewxbox"/> Data can be transferred from a previous console using a USB transfer cable sold separately.<ref name="chron-silm"/> If removed from its casing, a hard drive from a previous generation 360 can be implanted into the drive bay instead of purchasing a hard drive branded for use with the new model.<ref name="chron-silm">{{cite web|url=http://blog.chron.com/gamehacks/2010/07/picking-up-an-xbox-360-slim-read-this-first/ |title=Picking up an Xbox 360 Slim? Read this FIRST|publisher=Houston Chronicle |date=2010-07-22 |accessdate=2011-07-24}}</ref><ref name="insidenewxbox"/>
Unlike previous generations of the console which had names to distinguish different [[Stock-keeping unit|SKUs]], the new models' retail units were branded by their internal storage capacity<ref name="360 Arcade replacement">{{cite web |url=http://e3.gamespot.com/story/6265465/new-200-xbox-360-planned-elite-and-arcade-getting-50-price-cut |title=New $200 Xbox 360 planned, Elite & Arcade getting $50 price cut |first=Tor |last=Thorsen |date=14 June 2010 |work=GameSpot |publisher=CBS Interactive |accessdate=2010-06-17 |quote=Moore said that Microsoft is currently working on a second new Xbox 360, which will be offered at the arcade's price point of $200. He declined to say what functionalities the cheaper model would or would not have. [...] One likely scenario is the cheaper model will essentially be a slim arcade with no Wi-Fi capabilities or a hard drive. [...] Moore also said that going forward, all future models of the Xbox 360 would not have names and would only be designated by their memory capacity. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/61Dn0CKcs?url=http://e3.gamespot.com/story/6265465/new-200-xbox-360-planned-elite-and-arcade-getting-50-price-cut |archivedate=26 August 2011 |df= }}</ref> in a similar fashion to current models of its main competitor the [[PlayStation 3]]. When the first new models began to ship, remaining stock of the Elite package dropped in price to US$249.99<ref name="360 Arcade replacement" /> or A$349<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.news.com.au/technology/microsoft-launches-kinect-and-slimmer-xbox-360/story-e6frfro0-1225879783329 | title=Microsoft reveals Kinect and slimmer Xbox 360 | first=Jennifer | last=Dudley-Nicholson | date=2010-06-15 | work=News Limited newspapers}}</ref> and the Arcade dropped to US$149.99.<ref name="360 Arcade replacement" />
===Xbox 360 S 250 GB model=== The first Xbox 360 S [[Stock-keeping unit|SKU]] revealed included a 250 GB hard drive<ref>{{cite web |url=http://mktplassets.xbox.com/NR/exeres/3EE4C7AF-0C7A-4B0D-92DC-83961F1B4F44.htm |title=Xbox.com — Hardware Catalog — Xbox 360 250 GB Console |work=Xbox.com |publisher=Microsoft |accessdate=2010-06-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111116063045/http://mktplassets.xbox.com/NR/exeres/3EE4C7AF-0C7A-4B0D-92DC-83961F1B4F44.htm |archivedate=2011-11-16 |df= }}</ref> and its casing featured a glossy black finish. It was shipped to US retailers the same day it was announced ({{date|2010-06-14|mdy}}) and went on sale later that week. It was released in Australia on {{date|2010-07-01|mdy}},<ref name="AUNZSlimPrice">{{cite web|author= Levi Buchanan |url=http://uk.xbox360.ign.com/articles/109/1097102p1.html |title=E3 2010: Xbox 360 Slims Down Today — Xbox360 News at IGN |publisher=Uk.xbox360.ign.com |date=2010-06-14 |accessdate=2010-11-11}}</ref> in New Zealand on {{date|2010-07-08|mdy}}<ref name="AUNZSlimPrice"/> and in Europe on {{date|2010-07-16|mdy}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/Microsoft_Xbox/status/16170140427 |title=Twitter / Suspended |publisher=Twitter.com|accessdate=2010-11-11}}</ref> It retails at [[United states dollar|US$]]299.99,<ref name="AUNZSlimPrice"/> [[Pound sterling|£]]199.99,<ref name="AUNZSlimPrice"/> [[Australian dollar|A$]]449.00,<ref name="AUNZSlimPrice"/> [[New Zealand dollar|NZ$]]499.00<ref name="AUNZSlimPrice"/> or [[Euro|€]]249.00,<ref>{{cite web|last=Beavis |first=Gareth |url=http://www.techradar.com/news/gaming/consoles/microsoft-announces-new-slim-xbox-360-696530 |title=Xbox 360 Slim announced by Microsoft | News | TechRadar UK |publisher=Techradar.com |accessdate=2010-11-11}}</ref> replacing the Xbox 360 Elite at that price point.
In August 2011, Microsoft announced they would be streamlining their models by discontinuing the glossy finish and that future 250 GB consoles would use the matte finish found on 4 GB models.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.teamxbox.com/xbox/24403/Xbox-360-S-Gets-a-Little-Less-Shiny/ |title=Xbox 360 S Gets a Little Less Shiny |publisher=TeamXbox |accessdate=2011-08-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111116060416/http://news.teamxbox.com/xbox/24403/Xbox-360-S-Gets-a-Little-Less-Shiny/ |archivedate=2011-11-16 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://majornelson.com/2011/08/12/the-official-word-on-the-glossy-xbox-360/ |title=The official word on the glossy Xbox 360 |publisher=[[Larry Hryb|MajorNelson.com]] |accessdate=2011-08-15}}</ref>
===Xbox 360 S 4 GB model=== A second SKU which included 4 GB of internal flash storage and had a matte black casing (much like the Xbox 360 Elite)<ref name="4GB Price 2"/> was released on {{date|2010-08-03|mdy}} in the US<ref name="4GB Price 2"/> and {{date|2010-08-20|mdy}} in Europe.<ref name="Euro4GBDate">{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/microsoft-confirms-kinect-price|title=Microsoft confirms Kinect price|publisher=[[Eurogamer]]|date=2010-07-20|accessdate=2010-07-21}}</ref> It replaced the Xbox 360 Arcade and is priced at [[United States dollar|US$]]199.99, [[Pound sterling|£]]149.99 or [[Euro|€]]199.99.<ref name="4GB Price 2">{{cite web|url=http://www.joystiq.com/2010/07/20/kinect-bundled-with-slim-4gb-xbox-360-arcade-for-300-new-conso/|title=Kinect bundled with slim 4GB Xbox 360 Arcade for $300, new console for $200 in August|date=2010-07-20|accessdate=2010-07-20|publisher=Joystiq|quote=''Though there are currently no Xbox 360 hard drives on the market that support the new "slim" form factor, Greenberg told us that this 4GB unit "absolutely does have that expansion bay that we have the opportunity to use in the future."''}}</ref><ref name="Euro4GBDate" /><ref name="4GB Price 1">{{cite web|url=http://zunited.net/2010/07/microsoft-announces-kinect-bundle-and-xbox-360-4gb-console/|title=Microsoft Announces Kinect Bundle And Xbox 360 4GB Console|date=2010-07-20|accessdate=2010-07-20|publisher=[zunited.net Zunited Microsoft Community]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101127201305/http://zunited.net/2010/07/microsoft-announces-kinect-bundle-and-xbox-360-4gb-console/|archivedate=2010-11-27|df=}}</ref><ref name="4GB Price 3">{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/5591653/new-xbox-360-model-hits-next-month-kinect-bundle-confirmed|title=New Xbox 360 Model Hits Next Month, Kinect Bundle Confirmed|date=2010-07-20|accessdate=2010-07-20|publisher=Kotaku}}</ref> Although this model has on-board storage, ''Xbox Product Director'' Aaron Greenberg confirmed that it does have a drive bay which Microsoft has "the opportunity to use in the future".<ref name="4GB Price 2"/> On {{date|2010-08-20|mdy}}, Microsoft announced a 250 GB stand-alone hard drive for use with Xbox 360 S models priced at US$129.99.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2010/08/20/xbox-360-s-250gb-hard-drive-sneaks-into-stores-microsoft-cackle/|title=Xbox 360 S 250GB hard drive sneaks into stores, Microsoft cackles as you fall into its trap (update: official)|date=2010-08-20|accessdate=2010-08-21|publisher=Joystiq|first=Paul|last=Miller}}</ref>
===Xbox 360 S 320 GB limited editions=== {{further|#Xbox 360 S special editions}} In June 2011, Microsoft announced a "Jon Jones Edition" Xbox 360 S console to coincide with the launch of [[Gears of War 3]], which featuring custom finish,<ref name="Gears3Console"/> a 320 GB hard drive<ref name="Gears3Console"/> and sounds from the Gears of War 3 game which are played when the console is switched on or the disc tray is opened.
Other 320 GB Xbox 360 S limited editions soon followed. Like the 250 GB "[[#Xbox 360 Super Elite|Super Elite]]" consoles, 320 GB Xbox 360 S consoles were only available as part of limited/special edition console bundles ({{as of|2011|09|df=US|lc=y}}), with stand-alone 320 GB hard drives also being available for purchase.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2011-10-11-ms-announces-320gb-xbox-360-hard-drive|title=MS announces 320GB Xbox 360 hard-drive News — Xbox 360 - Page 1 {{!}} Eurogamer.net|date={{Date|2011-10-11|mdy}}|accessdate={{Date|2011-10-11|mdy}}|publisher=[[Eurogamer]]|work=eurogamer.net}}</ref>
===Xbox 360 E=== [[File:Microsoft-Xbox-360-E-wController.jpg|thumb|right|Poopight|The Xbox 360 E, restyled with design traits of the [[Xbox One]]]] At Microsoft's E3 press conference on June 10, 2013, another hardware revision of the Xbox 360 known as '''E''' was unveiled for immediate availability. It is a revision of the S model with a new [[Xbox One]]-inspired casing, carrying a more rectangular appearance and a two-tone color scheme. It has one fewer USB port and no S/PDIF, YPbPr component or S-video connections.. Its internal hardware is otherwise similar to the S model.<ref name=geekcom-xboxe>{{cite web|title=Redesigned Xbox 360 E teardown reveals it’s a cost saver for Microsoft|url=http://www.geek.com/games/redesigned-xbox-360-e-teardown-reveals-its-a-cost-saver-for-microsoft-1558846/|work=Geek.com|accessdate=22 December 2013}}</ref> SKUs and pricing for the new model are identical to those of the previous model.<ref name=xbwire-2013model>{{cite web|title=Meet the New Xbox 360: With Spectacular New Titles and Free Games for Xbox Gold Members|url=http://news.xbox.com/2013/06/x360-xbox-360-e3-2013-reveal|work=Xbox Wire|publisher=Microsoft|accessdate=10 June 2013}}</ref><ref name=polygon-2013-360>{{cite web|title=Microsoft announced updated Xbox 360 console, available today|url=http://www.polygon.com/2013/6/10/4414972/microsoft-unleashes-updated-xbox-360-console-available-today|work=Polygon|accessdate=10 June 2013}}</ref>
==Discontinued models== [[File:Xbox-360-Arcade-wController.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Xbox 360 Arcade console with white wireless controller. The Arcade is cosmetically identical to the Core model.|alt=Xbox 360 Arcade console with white wireless controller.]]
===Xbox 360 Core=== The '''Xbox 360 Core''' was an entry level Xbox 360 which was later replaced with the "Arcade". Although available at launch in other regions, it was not available in Japan until November 2, 2006.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.joystiq.com/2006/09/07/microsoft-to-launch-xbox-360-core-in-japan/ |title=Microsoft to launch Xbox 360 Core in Japan |accessdate=2008-07-26 |last=Kietzmann |first=Ludwig |date=2006-09-07 |publisher=Weblogs, Inc.}}</ref> The Core system came bundled with a [[composite video]] cable, capable of only [[Standard-definition television|SDTV]] resolutions. The console was however capable of the same [[High-definition television|HDTV]] resolutions (up to [[1080i]]) as the other models when connected to a separately sold [[YPbPr|component]]/[[d-terminal]] cable. In October 2006, 1080p support was added for all models in a system update,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xbox.com/en-GB/community/news/systemupdate.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080731071201/http://www.xbox.com/en-GB/community/news/systemupdate.htm|archivedate=2008-07-31 |title=Latest update adds 1080p native support, Live Arcade upgrades and much, much more! |accessdate=2009-10-30}}</ref> including the "Core" using either the component/d-terminal cable, or the new VGA cable (although 1080p via component was not widely supported by televisions). It may also utilize a separately sold Xbox 360 hard drive. Unlike all other SKUs, it shipped with a wired version of the Xbox 360 controller, instead of the wireless version found in other SKUs.
===Xbox 360 [Pro/Premium]=== The '''Xbox 360'''<ref>{{cite web|title=Microsoft Announces Xbox 360 Price for Europe and North America|url=http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/news/press/2005/aug05/08-17EuropeNA360PricePR.aspx|publisher=Microsoft Corporation|accessdate=May 12, 2013}}</ref> (sometimes referred to as '''Pro''' or '''Premium''' and packaged as simply '''Xbox 360''' with the subheading "Go Pro") included all the features of the Xbox 360 Core and included a hybrid [[composite video|composite]]/[[component video|component]] cable with optional [[TOSLINK|optical out]] instead of the composite AV cable included with the Core. This model also included a detachable hard disk drive (initially 20 GB, while later models had 60 GB) to store downloaded content, provide compatibility with [[Xbox (console)|original Xbox]] games, and store game data. The included hard drive came with game demos, video clips and a free Live Arcade game, ''[[Hexic]] HD''. In July 2007, this version of the Xbox 360 began appearing with the Zephyr motherboard (the motherboard used in the Elite) which features HDMI 1.2 output and an improved GPU heatsink. Although this model did include an HDMI output,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.joystiq.com/2007/08/08/hdmi-premium-xbox-360-potentially-caught-on-film/ |title=HDMI Premium Xbox 360 caught on camera |accessdate=2008-07-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.engadget.com/2007/08/08/microsoft-officially-adds-hdmi-to-xbox-360-premium/ |title=Microsoft officially adds HDMI to Xbox 360 Premium |accessdate=2008-07-26}}</ref> it did not come with an HDMI cable.{{citation needed|date=February 2013}} Starting at the end of September 2007, the newest systems were shipped with the new "Falcon" motherboard. This motherboard includes the new 65 nm CPUs, making them quieter and cooler than the older systems.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gear.ign.com/articles/824/824183p1.html|title=Xbox 360 Falcon Mother Board and 65-nm CPU Arrive|last=Block|first=Gerry|publisher=IGN|date=2007-10-01|accessdate=2009-07-01}}</ref> On August 1, 2008, the 20 GB version was discontinued and was replaced by a 60 GB HDD model at the same price. Holiday 2008 consoles were bundled with ''[[Lego Indiana Jones: The Original Adventures]]'' and ''[[Kung Fu Panda (video game)|Kung Fu Panda]]''.<ref name="hol2008bundles" /> Price cuts that took effect on September 4, 2008 reduced the price from $349 to $299.<ref name="informationweek1"/> The Xbox 360 configuration, following its discontinuation, retailed for $250 until stocks were exhausted.[[File:Xbox-360-Pro-wController.jpg|thumb|upright|right|Xbox 360 Pro console with white wireless controller.]] ===Xbox 360 Elite=== [[File:Xbox-360-Elite-Console-Set.png|thumb|upright|Xbox 360 Elite console with black wireless controller|alt=Xbox 360 Elite console with black wireless controller.]] The '''Xbox 360 Elite''' included a 120 GB hard drive and a [[Gloss (material appearance)|matte]] black finish. The Elite retail package also included a controller and headset that match the system's black finish.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.xbox.com/en-US/hardware/xbox360elite/default.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070510235323/http://www.xbox.com/en-US/hardware/xbox360elite/default.htm |archivedate=2007-05-10 |title=Introducing Xbox 360 Elite |publisher=Microsoft Corporation|accessdate=2008-07-26}}</ref> The initial release price was $479.99 USD,<ref name="Elite unveiling">{{cite web |url=http://www.xbox.com/en-US/community/news/2007/0327-microsoftunveilsxbox360elite.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070405185941/http://www.xbox.com/en-US/community/news/2007/0327-microsoftunveilsxbox360elite.htm |archivedate=2007-04-05 |title=Microsoft Unveils Xbox 360 Elite |publisher=Microsoft Corporation|accessdate=2008-07-26}}</ref> [[Canadian dollar|C$]]549.99,<ref name="Elite unveiling"/> [[Pound sterling|£]]299.99, and [[Australian dollar|A$]]729.95. The Elite was released in North America on April 29, 2007,<ref>{{cite web | title = Happy Xbox 360 Elite launch day! | url = http://xbox.joystiq.com/2007/04/29/happy-xbox-360-elite-launch-day/ | accessdate=2009-11-25 | publisher = Joystiq}}</ref> Europe on August 24, 2007, and Australia on August 30, 2007. These Elites (and other Xbox 360 models using the Falcon) can be identified from earlier versions by a re-designed [[AC power plugs and sockets|power connector]] and a power supply rated to 175 W. In 2009, Elite models using the Jasper chipset became available. These can also be identified by their power supply, which is rated at 150W and has a 12.1A 12v rail. Christmas 2008 consoles were bundled with ''[[Lego Indiana Jones: The Original Adventures]]'' and ''[[Kung Fu Panda (video game)|Kung Fu Panda]]''.<ref name="hol2008bundles" /> The Elite's price tag was cut from $449 to $399 on September 4, 2008.<ref name="usatoday1"/><ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB125136429316263083 |title=2nd UPDATE: Microsoft Cuts High-End Xbox 360 Price By $100 |publisher=Online.wsj.com |date=2009-08-27 |accessdate=2009-09-10}}</ref> With the announcement of the new Xbox 360 250 GB model, the Elite dropped in price to US$249.99 for remaining units until stocks were exhausted.<ref name="360 Arcade replacement" />
===Xbox 360 Arcade=== The '''Xbox 360 Arcade'''<ref name=arcadefindsashelf>{{cite web| url= https://www.engadget.com/2007/10/12/xbox-360-arcade-finds-a-shelf-in-the-wild/ | title= Xbox 360 Arcade finds a shelf in the wild | accessdate= 2008-07-26 | author= Paul Miller | date= 2007-10-12 | publisher= Engadget}}</ref> replaced the Xbox 360 Core as the entry-level Xbox 360 on {{date|2007-10-23|mdy}}, while retaining the Core's price of [[United States dollar|US$]]279.99.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.shacknews.com/onearticle.x/49262|title= New Xbox 360 SKU Shows Up Online|accessdate= 2008-07-26|author= Carlos Bergfeld|date= 2007-10-02|publisher= Shacknews}}</ref> It was publicly revealed by Microsoft's president of Entertainment Devices division [[Robert J. Bach|Robbie Bach]] to the ''[[Financial Times]]'' on October 18, 2007,<ref name="360ArcadeAnnouncement">{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/news/6181267.html|title=$279 360 Arcade official|last=Magrino|first=Tom|publisher=Gamespot|date=2007-10-18|accessdate=2008-07-26}}</ref> and officially announced on October 22, 2007,<ref name=ArcadeConsolePR /> although it was available in stores far earlier.<ref name=arcadefindsashelf /> It included a wireless controller, a composite AV cable, HDMI 1.2 output, a 256 MB memory unit and five Xbox Live Arcade titles:<ref>{{cite web|url= https://arstechnica.com/gaming/news/2007/10/first-actual-pictures-of-xbox-360-arcade-bundle-leaked-with-packing-list.ars|title=First actual pictures of Xbox 360 Arcade bundle leaked, with packing list|accessdate= 2008-07-26|author= Ben Kuchera|date= 2007-10-11|publisher= Ars Technica}}</ref> ''[[Boom Boom Rocket]]'', ''[[Feeding Frenzy (video game)|Feeding Frenzy]]'', ''[[Luxor 2]]'', ''[[Pac-Man Championship Edition]]'', and ''[[Uno (video game)|Uno]]'' on a single disk, which also included a "Welcome Video" and several game trailers and demos.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.engadget.com/2007/10/14/xbox-360-arcade-unboxed/|title= Xbox 360 Arcade unboxed|accessdate= 2008-07-26|author= Conrad Quilty-Harper|date= 2007-10-14|publisher= Weblogs, Inc}}</ref> Like its predecessor the "Core", it did not include a hard disk drive, which is required for Xbox software backwards compatibility. In Autumn (Fall) 2008, with the introduction of the Jasper motherboard revision, the memory unit was removed from the package and replaced with a 256 MB internal memory chip.<ref name="256onboard">{{cite web|url=http://xbox.joystiq.com/2008/12/02/microsoft-confirms-256mb-internal-storage-in-xbox-360-arcade-uni/|title=Microsoft confirms 256 MB internal memory| accessdate=2009-11-07| publisher = Joystiq}}</ref> This was later upgraded to a 512 MB chip in Summer 2009.<ref name="512onboard">{{cite web|url=http://www.joystiq.com/2009/06/18/confirmed-new-xbox-360-arcade-systems-have-512-mb-onboard-memor/|title=Xbox 360 Jasper units with 512mb internal memory spotted in the wild| accessdate=2009-11-07| publisher = Joystiq}}</ref> Holiday 2008 consoles were [[Pack-in game|bundled]] with ''[[Sega Superstars Tennis]]''.<ref name="hol2008bundles" /> With the price cuts on {{date|2008-09-04|mdy}}, the Arcade fell from US$279 to US$199 in the US.<ref name="informationweek1">{{cite web|last=McDougall |first=Paul |url=http://www.informationweek.com/news/internet/b2c/showArticle.jhtml?articleID=210300528 |title=Xbox 360 Price Cuts Take Effect Friday |publisher=InformationWeek |date=2008-09-04 |accessdate=2009-09-10}}</ref> In the UK, with the 2009 Elite price drop and discontinuation of the "Premium" Pro [[Stock-keeping unit|SKU]], the Arcade price rose from [[Pound sterling|£]]129.99 to £159.99.<ref name="eurogamer.net">{{cite web |url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/ms-increases-arcade-360-price-in-uk |title=MS increases Arcade 360 price in the UK news |publisher=Eurogamer|accessdate=2009-11-11}}</ref> With the unveiling of the Xbox 360 S redesign, the Arcade dropped in price to US$149.99 for remaining units until stocks are exhausted. The Arcade was replaced at the US$200 price tier by the 4 GB Xbox 360 S.
===Xbox 360 Super Elite=== The Xbox 360 Elite has also been configured with a 250 GB hard disk drive and two wireless controllers on [[Xbox 360#Special editions|special limited editions]] of the console. Also referred to as the '''Xbox 360 Super Elite''',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.computerandvideogames.com/223527/news/ms-unveils-250gb-super-elite-360/|title=MS unveils 250GB 'Super Elite' 360|publisher=Computer and Video Games|accessdate=2011-07-18}}</ref> the console retailed at US$399.99, £249.99 and A$599.00<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ebgames.com.au/xbox/product.cfm?id=15737&refer=consoles |title=That page is missing! - EB Games Australia |publisher=Ebgames.com.au |accessdate=2010-11-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706103943/http://ebgames.com.au/xbox/product.cfm?id=15737&refer=consoles |archivedate=2011-07-06 |df= }}</ref> as of November 10, 2009. A ''[[Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2]]'' bundle included a special limited-edition black console featuring Modern Warfare 2 branding. Other bundles included a standard Elite finish and either the game ''[[Forza Motorsport 3]]''<ref name="250GB"/> or both ''[[Halo 3]]'' and ''[[Halo 3: ODST]]''.<ref name="can250">{{cite web|url=http://www.xbox.com/en-CA/community/news/2009/1201-xbox360elitespecial.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100109080528/http://www.xbox.com/en-CA/community/news/2009/1201-xbox360elitespecial.htm |archivedate=2010-01-09 |title=Microsoft Announces Canadian Exclusive Xbox 360 Elite Special 250 GB Edition including Halo 3 and Halo 3 ODST |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=2010-01-09 |accessdate=2011-08-24}}</ref> On March 9, 2010, alongside the release of ''[[Final Fantasy XIII]]'', Microsoft released another 250 GB bundle with the same extras as the Modern Warfare bundle except bundled with the ''Final Fantasy XIII'' game. Unlike other Super Elites, this console and its accessories featured the same white color scheme as "Pro" models. This bundle also included exclusive downloadable items for use with Xbox 360 avatars and a specially branded 250 GB hard drive.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cinemablend.com/games/Final-Fantasy-XIII-Special-Edition-Xbox-360-250GB-Bundle-Revealed-22836.html?catid=6&id=22836&tid=11743 |title=Final Fantasy XIII Special Edition Xbox 360 250GB Bundle Revealed |publisher=Cinemablend.com |accessdate=2010-11-11}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://marketplace.xbox.com/es-ES/Product/FINAL-FANTASY-XIII/66acd000-77fe-1000-9115-d802535107e4 |title=Xbox.com — Final Fantasy XIII |work=Xbox.com |publisher=Microsoft |language=Spanish |accessdate=2010-06-16 |quote=¡Hazte ahora con uno de los packs exclusivos de Final Fantasy XIII para Xbox 360! [...] Comprar [...] Xbox 360 Super Elite}}</ref> In April 2010, a ''[[Splinter Cell: Conviction]]'' Super Elite bundle featuring the same extras as the other bundles was released alongside the ''Splinter Cell: Conviction'' game.

*Wired controller *Composite AV Cable{{Ref|Model_comparison_table_note_b|[b]}} |US$299.99, £199.99, ¥27,800 |{{date|2005-11-22|iso}} |{{na}} |}
<div style="border:1px solid #aaa; padding:2px; background:#f9f9f9; font-size:smaller;"> '''All Xbox 360s come with Xbox Live Free membership (Prior to October 2010, the free service was known as ''Xbox Live Silver'')<ref name="XboxLiveFree">{{cite web|url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/31092/Microsoft_Renames_Xbox_Live_Silver_to_Xbox_Live_Free.php|title=Microsoft Renames Xbox Live Silver to 'Xbox Live Free'|author=Kyle Orland}}</ref> and a one-month trial of Xbox Live Gold membership (only new accounts are eligible).{{Clear}}''' '''All Xbox 360s are backwards compatible with [[List of Xbox games compatible with Xbox 360|supported]] [[Xbox (console)|Xbox]] titles as long as they have an Xbox 360 HDD attached. This can be purchased separately for the Core/Arcade pack.{{Clear}}''' '''All hard drives (included with a console or bought separately) come with the Xbox Live Arcade game [[Hexic HD]].{{Clear}}''' '''Included accessories match the color scheme of the console they are bundled with.{{Clear}}''' '''All European consoles also include a [[Xbox 360 accessories#Composite SCART Adapter Block|composite SCART adapter]] ([[Xbox 360 accessories#AV Connectors and Cables|''Advanced SCART AV Cable'']] sold separately).{{Clear}}'''
{{note|Model_comparison_table_note_a}}'''a''' 250 GB Elite consoles and 320 GB Xbox 360 S consoles are/were only available as part of limited/special edition bundles (see [[#Special editions|below]]).<br/> {{note|Model_comparison_table_note_b}}'''b''' The standard ''Composite AV Cable'' features three RCA connectors, for standard left and right channel audio and composite video, which supports an SD image ([[NTSC]] on NTSC consoles, [[PAL]] and [[PAL60]] on PAL consoles). It also lacks the TOSLINK connector found on all other (pre-2010) AV cables (including the ''Component HD AV Cable'').<br/> {{note|Model_comparison_table_note_c}}'''c''' The ''Component HD AV Cable'' features six RCA connectors, for standard left and right channel audio, composite video and HD component (YP<sub>B</sub>P<sub>R</sub>) supporting up to 1080p image.<ref name="OldComponent">{{cite web|url=http://www.xbox.com/en-US/hardware/x/xbox360componenthdcable/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090601193425/http://www.xbox.com/en-US/hardware/x/xbox360componenthdcable/ |title=Xbox.com {{!}} Catalog — Xbox 360 Component HD AV Cable |archivedate=2009-06-01 |accessdate={{Date|2011-03-16|mdy}} |publisher=[[Microsoft]] |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> It also features a [[TOSLINK]] optical audio connector, which supports either 2 channel (stereo) [[LPCM]] or [[Dolby Digital|dolby digital 5.1]].<br/> {{note|Model_comparison_table_note_d}}'''d''' The [[Xbox 360 accessories#Audio Dongle|audio dongle]] features two RCA connectors for left and right audio and a TOSLINK optical audio connector.<br/> {{note|Model_comparison_table_note_e}}'''e''' Compilation disk includes [[Boom Boom Rocket]], [[Feeding Frenzy (video game)|Feeding Frenzy]], [[Luxor 2]], [[Pac-Man Championship Edition]], and [[Uno (video game)|Uno]].{{Clear}} {{note|Model_comparison_table_note_f}}'''f''' Excluding Mexican and older Australian and New Zealand versions, where a [[Xbox 360 accessories#Universal Media Remote|Media Remote]] is bundled instead.<br/> {{note|Model_comparison_table_note_g}}'''g''' ''Component HD AV Cable'',{{Ref|Model_comparison_table_note_c|[c]}}{{Ref|Model_comparison_table_note_h|[h]}} [[Xbox 360 accessories#AV Connectors and Cables|HDMI cable]] and ''HDMI Audio Adapter''{{Ref|Model_comparison_table_note_d|[d]}} were included with the 120 GB model prior to September 2009.<br/> {{note|Model_comparison_table_note_h}}'''h''' ''Component HD AV Cable'' is replaced with a {{Nihongo|''D-Terminal HD AV Cable''|D 端子 HD AV ケーブル}} in Japan.<br/> {{note|Model_comparison_table_note_i}}'''i''' "Transforming D-Pad" controllers feature a [[d-pad]] that can be rotated to switch between either a "plus" (4-way) or a "disk" (8-way) d-pad. These controllers also feature different concave analog stick tops than standard controllers. </div>
==Special editions== [[File:Xbox 360 Halo 3 Special Edition.jpg|thumb|upright|''[[Halo 3]]'' special edition]] On a few occasions, Microsoft has produced [[special edition]]s of the console, usually to coincide with the release of a major product. These special editions are typically custom-colored Xbox 360 models, and are produced in limited numbers.
*At the [[Electronic Entertainment Expo|E3]] 2007 [[News conference|press conference]], Microsoft announced the ''[[Halo 3]]'' Special Edition console, released September 25, 2007. It sports a ''Halo 3'' theme on the console, a wired headset, a wireless controller, and a Play and Charge Kit. Other than the unique "Spartan green-and-gold" [[color scheme]], exclusive dashboard theme and downloads, and an HDMI port,<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.xbox.com/en-US/community/events/e32007/articles/halo3console.htm|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070713224019/http://www.xbox.com/en-US/community/events/e32007/articles/halo3console.htm|archivedate= 2007-07-13|title=Halo 3 Console Announced|accessdate= 2008-07-26|date= 2007-07-10|publisher=Microsoft}}</ref> its features were unusual in that it had the HDMI port present only on the elite, but the 20 GB hard drive of the premium.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xbox.com/en-US/hardware/x/xbox360halo3console/default.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080725042904/http://www.xbox.com/en-US/hardware/x/xbox360halo3console/default.htm|archivedate=2008-07-25|title=Halo 3 Special Edition Console| publisher=Microsoft|accessdate=2008-07-26}}</ref> It is priced at US$399.99 and £279.99 (the original price of the Xbox 360).<ref name="consoleprice">{{cite web |url=http://www.xbox.com/en-US/community/news/2007/0806-consoleprice.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070820211136/http://www.xbox.com/en-US/community/news/2007/0806-consoleprice.htm |archivedate=2007-08-20 |title=Microsoft Lowers Xbox 360 Price |publisher=Microsoft Corporation|accessdate=2008-07-26}}</ref> *To promote ''[[The Simpsons Movie]]'', Microsoft created a specially designed, yellow Xbox 360 console.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.xbox.com/en-US/community/events/simpsonsmovie/winxbox360.htm|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080619023538/http://www.xbox.com/en-US/community/events/simpsonsmovie/winxbox360.htm|archivedate= 2008-06-19|title=Win A Limited Edition Xbox 360|publisher=Microsoft| accessdate=2008-07-26}}</ref> The configuration was based on the Xbox 360 package of the time, the only difference being the color scheme of the Xbox 360 console and wireless controller. The consoles were to be given out to winners of drawings taking place between July 18, 2007 and July 27, 2007, in which a name was randomly drawn each day in the "10 Days and 10 Chances to Win" sweepstakes.<ref name="simpsonssweepstakes">{{cite web|url= http://www.thesimpsons.com/sweepstakes/movie/index.htm|title= Limited Edition Simpsons Movie Xbox 360 Sweepstakes|accessdate= 2008-01-15|publisher=Fox Broadcasting Company}}</ref> 100 consoles were produced in total.<ref name="microsoftsimpsons360">{{cite web|url= http://www.prnewswire.com/cgi-bin/stories.pl?ACCT=104&STORY=/www/story/05-10-2007/0004585255&EDATE=|title= Xbox 360 Has Movie Fans Seeing Stars|accessdate= 2009-07-22|publisher=PR Newswire Association LLC}}</ref> *A ''[[Resident Evil 5]]'' bundle containing a red Xbox 360 Elite console was released on March 13, 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.joystiq.com/2009/02/25/major-nelson-unboxes-the-red-resident-evil-5-xbox-360-bundle?icid=sphere_blogsmith_inpage_joystiq |title=Major Nelson unboxes the red Resident Evil 5 Xbox 360 bundle [update] |publisher=Joystiq |author=Hinkle, David |accessdate=2009-02-26}}</ref> The bundle also contains a red, wireless controller and a black, wired headset.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.joystiq.com/2009/02/24/red-resident-evil-5-xbox-360-bundle-its-real/ |title=Red Resident Evil 5 Xbox 360 bundle: it's real! |publisher=Joystiq |author=Fletcher, JC |accessdate=2009-02-26}}</ref>
===Super Elite special editions=== *On September 15, 2009 Microsoft announced a special 250 GB hard disk limited edition version of the Xbox 360 Elite for ''[[Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2]]''. The unit is highlighted by special game product branding and includes two wireless controllers and a headset. This was the first Xbox 360 announced to come with a 250 GB hard drive.<ref name=250GB>{{cite web |url=http://www.xbox.com/en-US/press/2009/0915-mw2.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100107131653/http://www.xbox.com/en-US/press/2009/0915-mw2.htm |archivedate=2010-01-07 |title=Limited Edition Console for ''Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2'' |publisher=Microsoft |date=2009-09-15 |accessdate=2009-10-01}}</ref> *A ''[[Final Fantasy XIII]]'' 250 GB limited edition bundle of the Xbox 360 console was announced on February 11, 2010 and was released to coincide with the release of Final Fantasy XIII (March 9, 2010). The bundle includes an imprinted white 250 GB Xbox 360 Elite (Final Fantasy XIII imprinted where HDD size imprint goes), two wireless controllers, a copy of Final Fantasy XIII and exclusive downloadable avatar items. Other than the HDD imprint, this console is cosmetically identical to the discontinued Pro models.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xbox.com/en-US/Press/archive/2010/0212-x10|title=Get Ready for the Biggest Year in Xbox 360 Gaming History|date=2010-02-11|work=|publisher=Microsoft|accessdate=2010-03-20|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101115041610/http://www.xbox.com/en-US/Press/archive/2010/0212-x10|archivedate=2010-11-15|df=}}</ref> *In March 2010, Microsoft announced a special limited edition black Xbox 360 Elite console for ''[[Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell: Conviction]]''. The unit includes a 250 GB hard drive, two black wireless controllers, a black wired headset, an Ethernet cable, a standard definition Composite A/V cable, and the standard edition version of the game.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xbox.com/en-US/press/2010/0302-sccspecialedition.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100307160806/http://www.xbox.com/en-US/press/2010/0302-sccspecialedition.htm|archivedate=2010-03-07|title=Xbox 360 Splinter Cell Conviction Special Edition Announced|author=|date=2010-03-02|work=|publisher=Microsoft|accessdate=2010-03-20}}</ref>
===Xbox 360 S special editions===
====250 GB models==== *A ''[[Halo: Reach]]'' special edition bundle was made available concurrently with the game on {{date|2010-9-14|mdy}}. It consists of a custom branded silver 250 GB Xbox 360 S console, two silver and black branded controllers, a black [[Xbox 360 accessories#Headset|wired headset]] and a copy of the game. The press release in which it was announced also revealed that it "not only captures the look and feel of the game, but also features custom sound effects from the Halo universe". The bundle retailed for US$399. The branded controllers and headset were also sold as standalone products.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.joystiq.com/2010/07/22/halo-reach-xbox-360-bundle-available-september-14-for-399/|title=Halo Reach Xbox 360 bundle available September 14 for $399|date=2010-07-22|accessdate=2010-07-23|publisher=Joystiq}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2010/07/22/new-xbox-360-250gb-limited-edition-halo-reach-bundle-revealed/|title=New Xbox 360 250GB Limited Edition Halo: Reach bundle revealed|author=Ross Miller|publisher=[[Engadget]]|date=2010-07-22|accessdate=2010-07-24}}</ref>
====320 GB models==== *In June 2011, Microsoft announced a "Limited Collector's Edition" (LCE) Xbox 360 S console to coincide with the launch of ''[[Gears of War 3]]''.<ref name="Gears3Console"/> The console features a high-gloss red finish with black Gears of War 3 Branding.<ref name="Gears3Console"/> Unlike other Xbox 360 S consoles, the Gears of War 3 LCE features a 320 GB hard drive.<ref name="Gears3Console"/> and sounds from the ''Gears of War 3'' game are played when the console is switched on and off or the disc tray is opened.<ref>{{cite web|title=Announcing the Xbox 360 Gears of War 3 Limited Edition Console|url=http://majornelson.com/2011/06/06/announcing-the-xbox-360-gears-of-war-3-limited-edition-console/|publisher=[[Larry Hryb|Major Nelson.com]]|accessdate=August 25, 2011}}</ref> It is bundled with two custom branded gloss red ''Gears of War 3'' wireless controllers, a wired headset, a copy of the game and a download code for additional in-game content.<ref name="Gears3Console"/> It was released on September 20, 2011.<ref name="Gears3Console"/> *On July 21, 2011, Microsoft announced the "Limited Edition Kinect Star Wars Bundle".<ref name="StarWarsConsole">{{cite web|url=http://majornelson.com/2011/07/21/limited-edition-star-wars-console/|title=Xbox Live's Major Nelson » Limited Edition Star Wars Console|date={{Date|2011-07-21|mdy}}|accessdate={{Date|2011-07-22|mdy}}|publisher=Microsoft}}</ref> The bundle includes a 320 GB Xbox 360 S console, which features [[R2-D2]]-based artwork and custom R2-D2-themed power on/tray eject sounds, a white [[Kinect]] sensor, a gold and black [[C-3PO]] themed wireless controller, a copy of ''[[Star Wars Kinect]]'' and ''[[Kinect Adventures]]'', and exclusive downloadable content.<ref name="StarWarsConsole"/> It was subsequently delayed until April 3, 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=Star Wars Kinect and Console Bundle Reportedly Delayed|url=http://news.teamxbox.com/xbox/24562/Star-Wars-Kinect-and-Console-Bundle-Reportedly-Delayed/|publisher=Team Xbox|accessdate=August 25, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111223233903/http://news.teamxbox.com/xbox/24562/Star-Wars-Kinect-and-Console-Bundle-Reportedly-Delayed|archivedate=December 23, 2011|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Kinect Star Wars Bundle & Game being released April 3rd|url=http://majornelson.com/2012/02/07/kinect-star-wars-bundle-game-being-released-april-3rd/|publisher=Microsoft|accessdate=February 12, 2012}}</ref> *On September 2, 2011, Microsoft announced the "Limited Edition Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3 Bundle". The bundle includes a 320 GB Xbox 360 S console, which features ''[[Modern Warfare 3]]'' based artwork and custom ''Modern Warfare 3'' themed power on/tray eject sounds, two ''Modern Warfare 3'' themed wireless controllers (with transforming d-pad), a black wired headset, and a copy of the game.<ref name="MW3-320GB">{{cite web|url=http://majornelson.com/2011/09/02/xbox-360-limited-edition-call-of-duty-modern-warfare-3-console-wireless-headset-with-bluetooth-and-wireless-controller/|title=Xbox Live's Major Nelson » Xbox 360 Limited Edition Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3 Console, Wireless Headset with Bluetooth and Wireless Controller|date={{Date|2011-09-02|mdy}}|accessdate={{Date|2011-09-03|mdy}}|publisher=Microsoft|work=majornelson.com}}</ref> The console was released on November 8, 2011 in North America, Australasia and the EMEA (Europe, Middle East and Africa) region.<ref name="MW3-320GB"/> *On July 14, 2012, Microsoft announced the "Limited Edition Halo 4 Bundle". The bundle was released on November 6, 2012, alongside the game.<ref name="Halo 4"/> The bundle includes a 320 GB Xbox 360 S, featuring a translucent case with ''[[Halo 4]]'' themed artwork and power on/tray eject sounds, two exclusive ''Halo 4'' themed wireless controllers, a wired headset, a copy of the game, and exclusive DLC.<ref name="Halo 4"/> The ring of light and power indicator on this console and its accompanying controllers are blue rather than the green found on other Xbox 360 models.<ref name="Halo 4">{{cite web|title=Halo 4 Limited Edition Bundle Announced |url=http://majornelson.com/2012/07/14/xbox-360-limited-edition-halo-4-console-bundle-accessories-revealed-at-san-diego-comic-con/ |date=2012-07-14|accessdate=2012-09-19}}</ref>
==Xbox 360 Launch Team Edition== {{Unreferenced section|date=February 2011}} [[File:specialeditionlaunchteamconsolexbox360.jpg|thumb|upright|The Launch Team console with controller]] A white console with green accents was released in 2005 only to the Launch Team as a gift from [[Microsoft]]. The consoles came complete with a 20 GB HDD also in green to match the top and bottom sections that are typically grey in color. The HDD plate was also personalized and engraved with the team member's [[gamertag]]. Few examples have been seen with simply the console release date November 22, 2005 engraved on the HDD plate. The consoles came with a limited issue controller to accompany the console. The difference with the controller again is the grey part on the controller is replaced with a green molded plastic, not painted contrary to popular belief, to match the console. Each console came with a plain white faceplate. However, as an additional gift, each team member was given an additional packaged faceplate with one of a kind art with the caption "I Made This" on the USB door of the faceplate. Very few examples have been sold off from original team member's collection. [[Larry Hryb]], better known as "Major Nelson", is known to own one which he displays pictures of on his website having been a member of the Launch Team. The special edition Launch Team console, hard drive, controller and the special faceplate were never sold in stores or meant for the general public. It is unknown yet how many of these very rare consoles exist today.
==Holiday bundles== As with the original Xbox, Microsoft has continued bundling two video game titles in console retail packaging during the [[Christmas and holiday season|holiday season]]. During the holidays of 2007, the Xbox 360 Pro and Elite packages were bundled with ''[[Forza Motorsport 2]]'' and ''[[Marvel: Ultimate Alliance]]''.<ref name=holidayconsoles>{{cite web|url=http://www.xbox.com/en-US/community/news/2007/1008-holidayconsoles.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011012329/http://www.xbox.com/en-US/community/news/2007/1008-holidayconsoles.htm|archivedate=2007-10-11|title=Holiday Consoles Include Two Free Games|accessdate=2008-01-22|publisher=Microsoft}}</ref> In the UK, Ireland and the Netherlands, ''Forza Motorsport 2'' was bundled with ''[[Viva Piñata]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B000YIMXD0 |title=Wireless Entertainment Pack 2 for Xbox 360 (Includes Forza 2, Viva Pinata and Wireless Controller) - Xbox 360 Console Sold Separately |publisher=Amazon.co.uk |accessdate=2009-09-10}}</ref>
Holiday 2008 Xbox 360 and Xbox 360 Elite packages were bundled with ''[[Lego Indiana Jones: The Original Adventures]]'' and ''[[Kung Fu Panda (video game)|Kung Fu Panda]]'', while Arcade consoles were bundled with ''[[Sega Superstars Tennis]]''.<ref name="hol2008bundles">{{cite web |url =http://news.softpedia.com/news/Xbox-360-Bundles-LEGO-Indiana-Jones-and-Kung-Fu-Panda-95385.shtml|title=Xbox 360 Bundles LEGO Indiana Jones and Kung Fu Panda|accessdate=2008-11-16|author=Dumitrescu, Andrei|date=2008-10-10|publisher= [[Softpedia]]}}</ref> Holiday 2009 packages included an Elite console, [[LEGO Batman]] and [[Pure (video game)|Pure]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-13506_3-10363475-17.html|title=New Xbox 360 holiday bundle announced|first=Don|last=Reisinger|work=CNET|date=2009-09-29|accessdate=2011-09-06}}</ref> Holiday 2010 bundles included a 250 GB Xbox 360 S console, [[Forza Motorsport 3]] and a voucher to download [[Alan Wake]] from the [[Xbox Live Marketplace]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.joystiq.com/2010/11/02/xbox-360-bundle-with-alan-wake-forza-3-confirmed-for-us/|title=Xbox 360 bundle with Alan Wake, Forza 3 confirmed for US|first=Richard|last=Mitchell|work=Joystiq|date=2010-11-02|accessdate=2011-09-06}}</ref>
Two bundles were available in the 2011 holiday season. The first, which retailed for US$399.99, contained a 250 GB Xbox 360 S, Kinect sensor, a copy of Kinect Adventures, a download voucher for [[Carnival Games (series)|Carnival Games: Monkey See Monkey Do]] and 3 months of Xbox Live Gold. The second, which retailed for US$299.99 contained a 250 GB Xbox 360 S, [[Fable III]], a download voucher for [[Halo: Reach]], and 3 months of Xbox LIVE Gold.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://majornelson.com/2011/10/18/xbox-360-250gb-holiday-bundles/|title=Xbox 360 250GB Holiday Bundles|first=Larry|last=Hyrb|date=2011-10-18|accessdate=2012-03-19}}</ref>
During the 2012 holiday season, Microsoft released several Xbox 360 S bundles at temporarily discounted prices, including a 4 GB Xbox 360 console with a Kinect sensor, ''[[Kinect Adventures]]'', and ''[[Kinect Disneyland Adventures]]'' for US$249.99; and a 250 GB Xbox 360 console with a physical copy of ''[[Forza Motorsport 4]] (Essentials Edition)'' and a digital download voucher for ''[[The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim]]'' for US$249.99.
For the 2013 holiday season, there were three Xbox 360 S bundles available, with each including one month of Xbox Live Gold. The 250GB Kinect Holiday Value Bundle included ''[[Kinect Sports: Season Two]]'', ''[[Kinect Adventures!]]'', and a download voucher for ''[[Forza Horizon]]''. The 4GB Kinect Holiday Value Bundle included ''Kinect Sports: Season Two'' and ''Kinect Adventures!''. The 250GB Holiday Value Bundle included ''[[Halo 4]]'' and a download voucher for ''[[Tomb Raider (2013 video game)|Tomb Raider]]''.
In 2014, three Xbox 360 E bundles were sold, all with one month of Xbox Live Gold included. The 500GB Holiday Value Bundle included ''[[Call of Duty: Ghosts]]'' and a download voucher for ''[[Call of Duty: Black Ops II]]''. A similar bundle, with a blue console and controller, was sold at [[Walmart]]. A 4GB Kinect Bundle was sold at [[Target Corporation|Target]], including ''[[Kinect Adventures!]]'', ''[[Kinect Sports]]'', and ''[[Forza Horizon]]''.

page.title: List of largest pharmaceutical companies by revenue

revision.comment: /* Top pharmaceutical companies with revenue greater than $10 billion */
revision.text:
The following is a list of the top independent pharmaceutical & biotechnology companies ranked by their revenue generated ($10 billion) in the respective financial year, it does not include biotechnology companies that are now owned by, or part of, larger pharmaceutical groups. The change is the companies relative position in this list, compared to their relative position in the prior year; i.e., an increase would be moving closer to rank 1 and vice versa. Green cells indicate years where revenue increased compared to the previous year, red cells indicate those years where there has been a decrease. ==Top pharmaceutical companies with revenue greater than $10 billion== {|class="sortable wikitable" !width=25|Rank !Chg !Company !width=100|{{nowrap|2018}}
